Info.title: Urban Traffic Flow Prediction Using LSTM and GRU

Abstract: For smart cities, the issue of how to solve traffic chaos has always attracted public attention. Many studies have proposed various solutions for traffic flow prediction, such as ARIMA, ANN, and SVM. With the breakthrough of deep learning technology, the evolutionary models of RNN, such as LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) and GRU (Gated Recurrent Units) models, have been proven to have excellent performance in traffic flow prediction. By using LSTM and GRU models, we explore more features and multi-layer models to increase the accuracy of traffic flow prediction. We compare the prediction accuracy of LSTM and GRU models in urban traffic flow prediction. The data collected in this study are divided into three categories, namely “regular traffic flow data”, “predictable episodic event data”, and “meteorological data”. The regular traffic flow data source is the “Vehicle Detector (VD) data of Taipei Open Data Platform”. Predictable episodic event data are predictable as non-routine events such as concerts and parades. We use a crawler program to collect this information through ticketing systems, tourism websites, news media, social media, and government websites and the meteorological data from the Central Meteorological Bureau. Through these three types of data, the accuracy in predicting traffic flow is enhanced to predict the degree of traffic congestion that may be affected.

General Computer Science.reason: The abstract discusses algorithms and data analysis, which are fundamental to computer science.

Computer Science (miscellaneous).reason: This serves as a general catch-all for aspects of the work that don't neatly fit into other specific categories.

Artificial Intelligence.reason: The abstract explicitly mentions and utilizes deep learning models (LSTM, GRU), which are core components of AI.

Computational Theory and Mathematics.reason: The underlying principles of deep learning models and traffic flow prediction involve mathematical and statistical concepts.

Computer Graphics and Computer-Aided Des.reason: Not directly relevant, although visualization of traffic data might be a minor aspect.

Computer Networks and Communications.reason: The author's expertise includes wireless networks and mobile communications, which are relevant to data collection and smart city applications. Traffic data is often collected and transmitted via networks.

Computer Science Applications.reason: The research focuses on a specific application: traffic flow prediction in smart cities. This is a clear application of computer science techniques.

Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition.reason: While not explicitly stated, traffic flow prediction can be seen as a form of pattern recognition in time-series data.

Hardware and Architecture.reason: Not directly relevant to the abstract.

Human-Computer Interaction.reason: Indirectly relevant, as the results of traffic prediction could be used in systems that interact with humans (e.g., navigation apps).

Information Systems.reason: The collection, storage, and processing of traffic data constitute an information system.

Signal Processing.reason: Traffic flow data can be viewed as a time-series signal, and signal processing techniques might be applicable.

Software.reason: The implementation of the LSTM and GRU models, the crawler program, and the data analysis tools all involve software development.
